title: feat(editor): make grammer highlights more visible

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
Apologies if this is a duplicate, but I couldn't find anything.
<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

VS code will helpfully highlight linting / grammar errors in a file with a green squiggly line. The location of errors in a file also shows up as a green "notch" in the scroll bar area (also very helpful).

Sometimes though, a highlighted grammar error is very small--maybe a single character. In these cases I find it very hard to visually scan a file to find the highlighted section. I oftentimes find myself relying on the scroll bar to show me where an error is by
1. clicking on a line
2. inspecting the scrollbar area to see where the cursor indicator is in relation to the green grammar error "notch" indicator.
3. Do a "guestimate" of how many lines down the error is in the file, and click on that line.
4. Inspect the scrollbar area to see if the cursor is on the same line as the grammar error.
   - If yes, closely inspect the current line to find the grammar error.
   - If no
     - Is the grammar error above the current line? If so, do a "guestimate" of how many lines up the error is in a file and click on that line. Repeat step 4.
     - Is the grammar error below the current line? If so, do a "guestimate" of how many lines down the error is in a file and click on that line. Repeat step 4.

Obviously this workflow isn't ideal. It would be very helpful if grammar errors showed up in the line number gutter area on the left side of an open editor pane (in a similar manner to how line additions / deletions receive an indicator in the line number gutter area of a file). This would make visually scanning a file to find a grammar error much easier, as I could use the scroll bar indicator to jump to the approximate area of the grammar error, and then scan the line number gutter area to find the line the grammar error is on.

Sorry if this is a confusing explanation. I don't know of a "proper" name for these UI components.

Thanks!

*Search terms:
grammar error visibility; linting error visibility; syntax error visibility*

This would be helpful!

title: Allow changing triple-click (and double-click) behaviour

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
Currently when I triple-click a word, the whole line gets selected.

I'm finding this annoying, as I seem to be doing it by accident, when intending to double-click to select just one word.

So I want to be able to customize triple-click to behave identically to double-click.

Searching user settings I cannot find anything for "triple". I also cannot find anything for controlling double-click behaviour. Or even how to define the action for "select word" and "select line". (I've also checked the keymap config, in case mouse actions were in there.)

(That is surprising, so if the config options I want already exist, then my feature request is to make them more easily discoverable!)

title: Verify source maps

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

body:
Today I saw another problem with breakpoints not being hit because the sourcemap's `sourceRoot` was wrong (because it was configured incorrectly in the tsconfig.json).

The fix was trivial for me, but for a user it is not obvious what the problem is. Hovering over the grey breakpoint just shows a not very informative message "unverified breakpoint". 

And not many users are aware of the ".scripts" utility that can be run on the debug console to see the source mappings in detail. And the output of ".scripts" is a bit verbose and does not highlight errors. See this example from node-debug which has a wrong `sourceRoot` entry in the source map of sourceMaps.js:

![2018-08-30_11-33-33](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1898161/44843570-e4bcc780-ac48-11e8-86f3-6397339dc2d8.png)

I think we can and should do better!

My proposal:

For obvious reasons we cannot show a warning message when an expected breakpoint is **not** hit.
But we could do an upfront verification pass over all generated files reachable via the `outFiles` globs and if they have a source map reference at the end we can verify that the source map exists and that contained back reference to the source is points to an existing file.
If the verification process sees error, we could show detailed information about the problem.
In order to keep the amount of information small, we could limit the verification to only those source files that actually have breakpoints.
 
This verification can be implemented in basically three ways:
- inside the DA in "launch" or "attach" when the launch config is available. The output of the verification could be send to the debug console in text form and we could either treat problems as fatal and abort debugging or as informative and continue debugging. The verification could use the ".scripts" tool and verify the paths in its output and only show the errors.
- inside the node-debug extension: here we could verify the launch config and the source maps in the `resolveDebugConfiguration` method which makes it possible to show nicer UI and ask the user whether he wants to continue or abort debugging. Another advantage of doing the verification in the extension code is that the code is shared for both node-debug and node-debug2.
- inside a separate extension. This approach could be useful for any debugger that uses sourceMaps. But since launch configs are not standardized, it is difficult to find and interpret the relevant attributes correctly. 

@roblourens what do you think?

/cc @dbaeumer

title: Crashes when opens Huge Files [bug]
body: Issue Type: Bug Found a bug. When you clicked to open huge file, for ex. 1.5 GB txt, and then immediately closed it - VS Code will try to open it anyway, RAM will be overflow, and Studio crashes. VS Code version: Code 1.26.1 (493869ee8e8a846b0855873886fc79d480d342de, 2018-08-16T18:38:57.434Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.17134

title: Copy with syntax highlighting doesn't work
body:
Using the latest version of VS Code I don't get the copy with syntax highlighting working as I would expect.

When I copy code in one VS Code window (e.g. C# file) and then paste the code into another VS Code window where I am editing a markdown file then the pasted code is plain text and not HTML formatted. Seems like this feature doesn't work at all, because there is no format whatsoever applied when I paste it.

According to [this comment](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/3518#issuecomment-304152929) it should copy it as HTML into the clipboard and given that I am pasting it into a markdown file I would expect that VS Code will paste the HTML formatted code.

Looks like that VS Code doesn't respect its own features or maybe it's just fundamentally not working as expected?

title: Support debugging on a Node.js WebSocket source
body:
Hello, I'd like to ask for a feature. That is to support remote debugging on a Node.js target, which has only a WebSocket link. Currently I have to use chrome devtool to do this, by using this link: 

```
chrome-devtools://devtools/bundled/inspector.html?v8only=true&ws=
```

But if I fill my WebSocket debug link in the `address` field in `launch.json`, it does not work at all.

Thanks!

title: Support filtering tasks activities by file type (language)

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
I guess this is related to #1167 but was closed, however I don't think that version 2 of the tasks api properly supports this.

In fact, in my workspace I've multiple files for different languages (scripts and such plus the actual sources), and when hitting my build keybinding I'd like the activity panel to only show the tasks which are relevant for such language (or for the whole project, if any is defined as "global"), and not all the tasks defined.

title: Multiple environment profiles (either per-session or per-window)
body:
VS Code is awesome, and others have taken a liking to it as well. So much so that whole IDEs are being built on top of extensions (such as PlatformIO, vs-code-arudino, Flutter, etc.)

What this means is that I typically have VS Code open three/four times (e.g. one for PlatformIO, one for Arduino, one for Python). While it's awesome I can hotswap between them, PlatformIO makes some changes to the UI that only make sense to it (e.g. there's a virtualenv I didn't realize I was in and was wondering why Python3 sources were being interpreted as Python2.7)

There's also occasionally extensions that conflict with one another -- For instance, the PlatformIO plugin just does not play well with the Arduino plugin, both try to take over parts of the interface in different ways. 

There's already setting, `--extensions-dir` and `--user-data-dir` in combination,  that lets you swap what directory extensions are loaded from. I'm more asking "Can I have per-window choices of extensions?" Barring that, a simple way to declare an extension-set and fire up Code with that?

And maybe it should be showing the `?blah` too?

title: Linux ssh-agent/ssh-askpass problem

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. --> 
<!-- Also please test using the latest insiders build to make sure your issue has not already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->

As already reported in #33814, #32097, #52137 the bug isn't fixed for me and the workarounds don't work either

<!-- Use Help > Report Issue to prefill these. -->
```
VSCode Version: 1.26.1
OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04
Date: 2018-08-16T18:34:20.517Z
Electron: 2.0.5
Chrome: 61.0.3163.100
Node.js: 8.9.3
V8: 6.1.534.41
Architecture: x64
Shell: zsh
```

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a Git repo folder
2. Call a Git action like sync, push etc

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes



I'm using ssh-agent to keep all my keys opened and enter the passwords after I boot (`ssh-add ~/.ssh/id_rsa`). I can use git from the terminal without any problems, but "use the terminal then" is not a valid workaround for me when a whole feature doesn't work.
I've set some configs in my ~/.ssh/config file as well
```
Host *
  ServerAliveInterval 60
  AddKeysToAgent yes
  IdentityFile ~/.ssh/id_rsa
Host gitlab.com
  HostName gitlab.com
  User git
Host github.com
  HostName github.com
  User git
```

But it still get this error when using a feature that calls a remote git action:
```
> git pull --tags origin master
ssh_askpass: exec(/usr/bin/ssh-askpass): No such file or directory
Permission denied (publickey).
fatal: Could not read from remote repository.

Please make sure you have the correct access rights
and the repository exists
```

I already tried installing ssh-askpass with `sudo apt-get install ssh-askpass-gnome ssh-askpass` but he asks me every single time for a password, so the ssh-agent is ignored

title: ctrl+shift+a and ctrl+shift+e don't work in macOS

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. --> 
<!-- Also please test using the latest insiders build to make sure your issue has not already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issue to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.24.1
- OS Version: 10.13.2

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open file in vscode macOS
2. Place yourself on any given line
3. Use the key command `ctrl+shift+[e|a]`, observe nothing happens
4. Go to any other text editor or text field on the operating system
5. Attempt the same command, observe that it highlights everything to the left / right of the cursor respectively

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

---

Visual Studio Code seems to maintain the emacs-like behavior built into OSX of going to beginning and  end of line with `ctrl+e` and `ctrl+a` respectively. However, when throwing the shift key into the mix, it doesn't work. I'd assumed this was due to a conflicting key command, but couldn't find anything mapped to this, and those keys don't seem to trigger anything.

I'm sure this is a niche command, but I find myself using it quite often, and it's a killer when trying to use vscode.

title: Allow to have language without any surrounding pairs

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
Testing #57317

- Have following language configuration
```json
{
	"comments": {
		"lineComment": "REM"
	},
	"brackets": [
		["{", "}"],
		["[", "]"],
		["(", ")"],
	],
	"autoClosingPairs": [
		["{", "}"],
		["[", "]"],
		["(", ")"],
		["\"", "\""]
	],
	"surroundingPairs": [],
	"folding": {
		"markers": {
			"start": "^\\s*(::\\s*|REM\\s+)#region",
			"end": "^\\s*(::\\s*|REM\\s+)#endregion"
		}
	}
}
```
- Have following settings
```json
"editor.autoClosingBrackets": "languageDefined",
"editor.autoClosingQuotes": "languageDefined",
"editor.autoWrapping": "brackets"
```
- Open a new document with language having above configuration
- Type some text and select the text and type `{`
Expected: Text should not be auto surrounded as no surrounds pairs are configured
Observed: Text is auto surrounded by `{`

title: Add isVisible to OutputChannel
body:
Would it be possible to add an **isVisible** flag to OutputChannel objects, similar to the TreeView ? 

Already having 'show' and 'hide' functions, it would seem sensible to know if the channel is actually visible or not. 

I have a use case where if the user has hidden the output channel, I would just like to pop up a notification rather than reveal the output channel. I don't want to keep showing the output channel if the user has decided to hide it.

title: CSS grammer in endless loop

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
Refs: #57309

1. Open `repl.css`
2. Below line 6 type
`@import`
Notice error in console: [1] - Grammar is in an endless loop - Grammar pushed & popped a rule without advancing

body: Issue Type: Feature Request Testing #57304 There already is a 'Modified in Workspace" decoration, it would be great if that would also list any folders in which that setting is modified (and also show these in the workspace settings). VS Code version: Code - Insiders 1.27.0-insider (43676d0cb7db94e2fa771f1d10bff10eaa01b453, 2018-08-28T05:12:24.162Z) OS version: Darwin x64 17.7.0

title: Show other matching extensions button looks mis-aligned
body:
Testing #57306

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10746682/44710329-2b28ef80-aaac-11e8-81f8-319deac3259c.png)

- Not sure if it has to be that prominent. It can be rendered as link next to `No Settings Message`

Eg:

title: Settings UI lacks concept of inherited default value
body: re #57304 * open settings UI * locate 'Suggest Font Size' * notice how the UI shows `0` which isn't true - the default value is the font size of the editor.

title: Display complex CSS compatibility layout

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
In MDN, certain properties are shared between multiple contexts. For example, `justify-items` can be used in both `flex` and `grid` contexts.

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/justify-items

The Browser Compat Data looks like this: https://github.com/mdn/browser-compat-data/blob/master/css/properties/justify-items.json

In VS Code, we currently display the highest supported browser version. For example, if a property is supported by
- Chrome 30 in context A
- Chrome 40 in context B

We'll show `Chrome 40` as the compat string for Chrome.

MDN has a better layout for examining compat data:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4033249/44691664-6b3c9380-aa14-11e8-98df-79fbe7f525a8.png)

We should find a way to present compat data for multiple contexts.

title: Feature Request: Hotkey Support for QuickInputButton
body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
Issue Type: **Feature Request**
<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

As an extension developer I want to assign a hotkey to a custom [QuickInputButton](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/extensionAPI/vscode-api#QuickInputButton), that is active/enabled when the [InputBox](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/extensionAPI/vscode-api#InputBox) or [QuickPick<T>](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/extensionAPI/vscode-api#QuickPick%3CT%3E) is shown. This would enhance navigating through multi step input forms a lot. It should have similar behaviour like the [QuickInputButtons.Back](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/extensionAPI/vscode-api#QuickInputButtons) button which is by default assigned to <kbd>Alt</kbd> + <kbd>←</kbd>.  Further I want to allow the extension user to assign his/her preferred hotkey to that button, too. Therefore maybe "some link" to the `keybindings.json` would be applicable.

title: Quotation Marks of PHP and HTML Attributes are confused
body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. --> 
<!-- Also please test using the latest insiders build to make sure your issue has not already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issue to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.26.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 Home Version 1803 (Build 17134.228)

Extensions: ftp-sync (It still happened when it was disabled)
Steps to Reproduce:

1. Write someting like this in a PHP file:
`<div onclick='javascript:doSomething("<?php echo $parameters['something']");?>'>`

Which will look something like this:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/39553654/44623050-61584a80-a8c5-11e8-9724-fa73c1378c28.png)

**What I expexted to see:**

I expected it to look something like this:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/39553654/44623078-08d57d00-a8c6-11e8-9ddb-31d5e81e86ab.png)

**What is the issue?**

I think what happens is that VS Code thinks that the first two single quotation marks (the one after `onclick=` and the one after `parameters[` belong together. Therefore it comes to the conclusion that the rest after the second single quotation mark is wrong and colors it in a deep red. VS Code should not confuse quotation marks outside of PHP tags with quotation marks inside of PHP tags.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes
